content.question: Which of the following most directly pushed migrants from Asia and Africa to come to Europe in the 1950s to 1970s?

choices.label: Widespread famines forced large numbers of Africans and Asians to flee their home countries for Europe.
European political and economic integration reduced border controls.
Economic and political instability associated with decolonization drove many citizens of former colonies to seek new economic opportunities in Europe.
Increasing secularization in European society attracted victims of religious persecution.

content.answer: Economic and political instability associated with decolonization drove many citizens of former colonies to seek new economic opportunities in Europe.
